utterances: You taking my medicine like I...
We're waiting on them to bring us some--an utility trailer to work out of us...
Yeah.
...but we don't have any facilities to draw blood or do any kind of lab work right now.
An elderly Vietnamese man is waiting in folding chairs lined up on one side of the stage.
He's got an infected sore on his leg after wading in floodwaters filling his home.
And a family from Gulfport, Mississippi, has come here from a church in Mobile where they've been living since the storm.
A baby sleeps on Russell Sample's(ph) chest.
I've got my little grandbaby Autumn.
She's five months old, and I have my grandbaby Joslyn(ph).
She's 21 months old and my wife Tina.
We're going to move back to Mobile for a little while until Gulfport gets back on its feet, you know?
It's really bad.
It's really bad over there, so...
Your granddaughter is sick today?
Yeah, she's got the sniffles, a little runny nose and running a little fever, so--say hello Miss Debbie.
Tell her, `Oh, no, the trees fell down.
That's what she said at my mother's every tree...
Can I hold it?
You can hold it.
They told us about the doctor down here who was seeing folks.
So we thought we'd bring her on down here.
Benjamin is something of an institution in this town and in national health-care circles ever since she founded a rural health-care clinic here 15 years ago.
The Alabama native treats the working-class people in Bayou La Batre who fall between the cracks of Medicaid and private insurance.
She's moved her clinic to this stage where medicines are neatly arranged on shelves lining the walls and tables in the center serve as makeshift examine rooms.
This is a Red Cross shelter, so basically the supplies and things, the things we've gathered, and people are donating samples and things that we have.
And so we'll give them out as needed.
We ran out of tetanus and then we had to get some, so we got some yesterday because people are cutting themselves and limbs falling on them.
And the reality is setting in and so we're seeing a lot of mental health issues now that we didn't see two weeks ago.
(Soundbite of baby crying)
This isn't the first time Benjamin found herself trying to care for patients in a crisis without a clinic.
I had the experience of having gone through Hurricane Georges, where we lost things then in '98 and it took two years to rebuild.
And during that time, I just saw people out of my truck.
I made house calls.
But this time, we basically did the same thing, but I spent the first week, two weeks trying to get everything out of the building before everything mildewed.
So...
Have you been in touch with the government at all like FEMA and trying to get them to help you?
I've not been able to get through to FEMA.
The phone lines are just always busy and says, `Call later.
I've even tried to call at 2:00 in the morning, but there are just so many people trying to call that you just can't get through.
So I haven't been able to get through yet.
What would you want from them if you could get through?
The main thing for me personally is my clinic.
From the other storm, we went through FEMA and we were able to get an SBA loan and so I still own $190,000 on the SBA loan.

And basically what I want to do is defer those payments at least a month or two because the payment's due now and it's going to be due in two more weeks in October and I want to see if I can defer the payments another month or something till we at least get some kind of income coming in.
(Soundbite of tape)
Just a few miles away, workers are now taping up what they can salvage from Benjamin's family practice, a small modular building in downtown Bayou La Batre.
She remembers coming back to check on things the day after Katrina struck.
I drove up and I saw the outside of the building, and I said, `Oh, great, it was fine.
The building's here.
And I thought, `We missed it,' because it's up on pilings.
And then when I opened the door and the furniture was all on top of each other where you could see it just slushed around in here, I said, `No again.
Water got in here again enough to bounce furniture around,' so--and my heart just sank 'cause I knew what we'd have to go through.
(Soundbite of walking; car door open; car starting)
Dr.
Benjamin takes us on a tour.
Less than a block away at city hall, the official town emblem shows a muscular seaman casting his net.
Nearly everyone in this town of about 2,300 works in one way or another in the seafood industry: shrimpers, oystermen, crab pickers and packers, all out of work.
These are shipyards and some of these are seafood processing plants.
So we're going down the bayou now.
This is the working part of the town and all these places got flooded.
Here's some boats here.
See, they're up on dry land and turned over and, see, they really shouldn't be up on them.
Up on the seawall like that?
Yeah, they really shouldn't be up like that.
They should be in the water.
I mean, that looks almost like...
Dry dock.
...surreal.
I don't know how it's staying there.
This one's over in the trees.
The little oyster boat's over in the trees.
It's a scene repeated over and over as you drive down Shell Belt Road along the bayou.
As you look to the right, shrimp trawlers are heaped one on another far from the shore.
The boats have names like Crazy Cat(ph), Integrity(ph) and My Phuong.
About 30 percent of the people in Bayou La Batre are immigrants from Southeast Asia and a year ago the city elected its first Asian city council member, Phuong Huynh.
He says families have invested everything into shrimp boats, the ones that are now strewn on to dry land.
Most of them won't have the ability nor the money to hire some cranes to get the boats back in the water.
And hopefully most of them have insurance which I doubt it--which I doubt it.
How do you think the city is going to recover from this?
I don't know.
It just seems everywhere you look...
No, I don't know how long it's going to recover.
I don't know myself.
I'm going to turn where that red truck's going.
Across the street from the working waterfront on Shell Belt Road are homes.
Dr. Benjamin tells us to pull over at a small wood-framed structure to check on one of her patients, 10-year-old Jamis Schultz(ph).
What happened to your leg?
Well, I was catching a cat and I accidentally bumped it on something.
So you've got the scars here, scratches.
The skin's open so we need to get it cleaned up and basically put some bandages on it so it doesn't get infected 'cause you're around all this dirty stuff.
His parents, Jody and Charlene, are tense and tell Dr. Benjamin how worried they are about losing the family home because it has suffered so much damage.
So they're going to condemn your house.
You've got a number where I can get Dr. Mitchell to call you?
He's our state legislator on our board and maybe you can talk to him as well.
I sure do.
Well, let me write your number down and I'll get him to call you today.
OK.
